topics.title: Python Dictionaries
topics.description: Master dictionaries - key-value pairs, methods, nested dictionaries, and dictionary comprehension

contents.title: Introduction to Dictionaries
contents.content:
Dictionaries are unordered collections of key-value pairs. They are mutable and optimized for retrieving data when you know the key.

Dictionary Characteristics:
‚Ä¢ Unordered: No specific order (Python 3.7+ maintains insertion order)
‚Ä¢ Mutable: Can be modified after creation
‚Ä¢ Key-Value pairs: Each item has a key and value
‚Ä¢ Keys must be unique: Duplicate keys not allowed
‚Ä¢ Keys must be immutable: strings, numbers, tuples
‚Ä¢ Values can be any type: including lists, dicts

When to Use Dictionaries:
‚Ä¢ Store related data (user profile, product info)
‚Ä¢ Fast lookups by key
‚Ä¢ Represent JSON data
‚Ä¢ Count occurrences
‚Ä¢ Cache/memoization
‚Ä¢ Configuration settings

Dictionary vs List:
‚Ä¢ Dict: Access by key, unordered
‚Ä¢ List: Access by index, ordered
‚Ä¢ Dict: Faster lookups
‚Ä¢ List: Better for sequences

Common Operations:
‚Ä¢ Adding/updating items
‚Ä¢ Removing items
‚Ä¢ Accessing values
‚Ä¢ Checking key existence
‚Ä¢ Iterating through dict

contents.title: Creating and Using Dictionaries
contents.content:
# Creating dictionaries
person = {
    'name': 'Raj Sharma',
    'age': 25,
    'city': 'Mumbai',
    'is_student': False
}

print(person)  # {'name': 'Raj Sharma', 'age': 25, ...}

# Empty dictionary
empty_dict = {}
print(empty_dict)  # {}

# Using dict() constructor
user = dict(name='Priya', age=22, email='priya@example.com')
print(user)  # {'name': 'Priya', 'age': 22, ...}

# Accessing values
print(person['name'])  # Raj Sharma
print(person['age'])   # 25
# print(person['salary'])  # KeyError!

# Using get() method (safer)
print(person.get('name'))    # Raj Sharma
print(person.get('salary'))  # None (no error)
print(person.get('salary', 0))  # 0 (default value)

# Adding/updating items
person['email'] = 'raj@example.com'  # Add new key
person['age'] = 26  # Update existing key
print(person)

# Removing items
del person['is_student']  # Delete key
print(person)

age = person.pop('age')  # Remove and return value
print(age)  # 26
print(person)

last_item = person.popitem()  # Remove last item
print(last_item)  # ('email', 'raj@example.com')

# Check if key exists
if 'name' in person:
    print('Name exists')

if 'salary' not in person:
    print('Salary not found')

# Dictionary length
print(len(person))  # Number of key-value pairs

# Clear all items
person.clear()
print(person)  # {}

examples.title: Dictionary Methods and Operations
examples.code:
# keys(), values(), items()
user = {'name': 'Raj', 'age': 25, 'city': 'Mumbai'}

# Get all keys
keys = user.keys()
print(keys)  # dict_keys(['name', 'age', 'city'])
print(list(keys))  # ['name', 'age', 'city']

# Get all values
values = user.values()
print(list(values))  # ['Raj', 25, 'Mumbai']

# Get all key-value pairs
items = user.items()
print(list(items))  # [('name', 'Raj'), ('age', 25), ...]

# Iterating through dictionary
for key in user:
    print(f'{key}: {user[key]}')

for key, value in user.items():
    print(f'{key}: {value}')

# update() - merge dictionaries
user = {'name': 'Raj', 'age': 25}
more_info = {'city': 'Mumbai', 'email': 'raj@example.com'}
user.update(more_info)
print(user)  # All keys merged

# copy() - create shallow copy
original = {'a': 1, 'b': 2}
copy = original.copy()
copy['c'] = 3
print(original)  # {'a': 1, 'b': 2}
print(copy)      # {'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}

# fromkeys() - create dict with same value
keys = ['name', 'age', 'city']
default_dict = dict.fromkeys(keys, 'Unknown')
print(default_dict)
# {'name': 'Unknown', 'age': 'Unknown', 'city': 'Unknown'}
examples.explanation: Dictionary methods provide powerful ways to manipulate and iterate through dictionaries. Use items() for key-value iteration.
